column1: '''Diana Wynne Jones''' ([[16 August]] [[1934]] — [[26 March]] [[2011]]) was a British author of primarily fantasy fiction.

column2: Jones started studying English at St Anne's College in [[Oxford]]
column3: and attended lectures by both [[C.S. Lewis]] and [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] before graduating in [[1956]]. Concerning the difference between Lewis and Tolkien
column4: she has described the former as "booming to crowded halls and Tolkien mumbling to me and three others".<ref name=Something>Diana Wynne Jones
column6: in ''Reflections: On the Magic of Writing''
column7: p. 290</ref> Jones has remembered going to a "course of lectures" Tolkien gave on the subject of plots and stories
column8: but that "Tolkien was all but inaudible".<ref>Diana Wynne Jones
column9: "The Shape of the Narrative in ''The Lord of the Rings''"
column10: in ''Reflections: On the Magic of Writing''
column11: p. 6</ref> She has also given a more full account of Tolkien's lectures:<ref>Diana Wynne Jones
column13: in ''Reflections: On the Magic of Writing''

column1: {{blockquote|When I was a student I imagine I caused Tolkien much grief by turning up to hear him lecture week after week
column2: while he was trying to wrap his series up after a fortnight and get on with ''The Lord of the Rings'' (you could do that in those days
column4: and still get paid). I sat there obdurately despite all his mumbling and talking with his face pressed up to the blackboard
column5: forcing him to go on expounding every week how you could start with a simple quest narrative and
column6: by gradually twitching elements as it went along
column7: arrive at the complex and entirely different story of Chaucer's "Pardoner's tale" — a story that still contains the excitement of the quest narrative that seeded it. What little I heard of all this was wholly fascinating.}}

column1: [[Tom Shippey]] has commented that Jones' [[1983]] article "The Shape of the Narrative in ''The Lord of the Rings''" (which he describes as analysis of that work as "a series of movements
column2: each with its own coda") says more about the narrative of ''The Lord of the Rings'' "than
column4: Tolkien could".<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Tom Shippey]]|articleurl=http://www.the-tls.co.uk/tls/public/article1114176.ece|articlename=The magic of Diana Wynne Jones|dated=29 August 2012|website=[http://www.the-tls.co.uk/tls/ ''The Times Literary Supplement'']|accessed=1 October 2012}}</ref>
